texts.shortText:
Seabreams of the family Sparidae are particularly well represented in South Africa and include many important recreational and commercial fisheries species. They are laterally compressed, with a single continuous dorsal fin and forked tail. Most species are diurnal and form shoals on shallow temperate reefs, although some larger species are territorial and/or extend to 450 m depth. Many species change sex as they grow.

This species has a deep, silvery body and the blunt, rounded head typical of all stumpnose (and after which the common name is derived). It can be distinguished from other regional stumpnose by the single golden horizontal bar running along the side of adults from head to tail. In juveniles there are 5–6 fainter bars. There is also a small back spot at the base of the pectoral fin.
Up to 40 cm total length and a mass of up to 3.5 kg.

Global: Endemic to Southern Africa.

Local/Regional: St Helena Bay to southern Mozambique.

Juveniles use sheltered bays, estuaries and lagoons as nursery areas and are common around seagrass beds. They reach a length of about 10 cm after their first year, after which most return to the open sea. Adults occur in shoals over both rocky reefs and sandy bottoms from the shore to a depth of 50 m.

Juveniles graze on algae and seagrasses, but mostly only digest the epiphytic diatoms and encrusting invertebrates associated with these. Adults take a wide variety of invertebrates including echinoderms, crustaceans, molluscs, bryozoans and worms.
Do not change sex. Reach sexual maturity as a length of about 19–20 cm. Spawn inshore from July to February in the Cape (but in winter in KZN). Eggs develop in the plankton.

Body shape and habits similar to White stumpnose R. globiceps, but that species has dark vertical bars and lacks a horizontal golden band running along the side. Also similar to Tropical stumpnose R. sarba, but that species only occurs from Wilderness eastwards and has a golden spot in the centre of each scale, rather than a golden line along the side of the body.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fifth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 296).

Heemstra, P & Heemstra E (2004). Coastal Fishes of South Africa. NISC, Grahamstown. (p. 237).

Heemstra, P, Heemstra, E, Ebert, D, Holleman, W & Randall, J (2022). Coastal Fishes of the Western Indian Ocean. National Research Foundation & South African Institute for Aquatic Biodiversity, South Africa. Volume 3 (p. 311).

Smith, MM & Heemstra, P (eds.) (2003). Smith's Sea Fishes. Struik Publishers, Cape Town (p. 592).
